thread.title: BOM warns of heavy rain as potential cyclones form
thread.title_full: BOM warns of heavy rain as potential cyclones form

title: BOM warns of heavy rain as potential cyclones form
text:
BOM warns of heavy rain as potential cyclones form Weather News BOM warns of heavy rain as potential cyclones form By Kym Agius, Tuesday February 7, 2017 - 13:04 EDT 
There is a low to moderate chance two cyclones could form in Queensland waters later this week, the first for the season, the Bureau of Meteorology (BOM) has said.The two lows are developing in a large monsoon trough spanning northern Australia, which has already brought massive downpours to communities.There is a 20 to 50 per cent chance one of the lows could develop into a cyclone on Thursday .BOM forecaster Andrew Bufalino said if it did form, at this stage it could lose puff quickly as it tracked west towards and over Northern Territory land.He said there had been inconsistency between the models."We don't know if it has enough time to develop into a cyclone," Mr Bufalino said."There is definitely potential [to form], but into the weekend it is expected to drift further west and therefore it will decrease the threat, especially with the intensity."Given the time of development and how much time it has to intensify I would say it would be a weak system."In the east of the Coral Sea, Mr Bufalino said there was a 5 to 20 per cent chance of a low forming into a cyclone on Thursday or Friday.It is due to track east towards New Caledonia, outside of the BOM's monitoring site."Queensland's east coast is pretty safe in the short term," Mr Bufalino said."We've got diverging systems, one is going west and one is going east."Gulf communities pummelled by rainThe major concern is the heavy rainfall associated with the monsoon trough, leading to flash flooding across numerous riverine systems."That is probably the biggest threat," he said.Gulf communities, mainly on Queensland's peninsula, are already getting daily totals of between 100mm to 150mm, Mr Bufalino said.In the coming days the heavier rain is expected to spread further into the Gulf, where 24-hour rain totals could top 150mm.Weak cyclone seasonCyclones usually start developing after Christmas, but Mr Bufalino said it had been a slow start.There has been an active upper level westerly wind over Australia this summer, tearing any potential system up."It has been quiet anomalous how strong the westerlies are aloft," he said."It has been making the conditions quiet hard to develop."The climate guys are really looking into it. The whole southern hemisphere has been really quiet, not just the Australian basin." - ABC
